titleproper.value:
Guide to the Richard L. Gilbert Advertising Collection
                    <lb/>1960's-1970's
                    <lb/>
                    <num>PR 309</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Susan Kriete

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2014-09-17T10:10-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: 90 print advertisements and proofs by Richard L. Gilbert's advertising agency from the 1960's and 1970's.

p.value: <emph render="bold">Available by advance appointment only</emph>. To schedule an appointment, contact the Print Room Librarian at printroom@nyhistory.org. Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)
This collection should be cited as: Richard L. Gilbert Advertising Collection, PR 309, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.

A long-time resident of the Bronx neighborhood Riverdale, Gilbert became a frequent contributor to the "Point of View" column in the 
                <emph render="italic">Riverdale Press</emph> after retiring from advertising. He died at home on December 29, 2013.

The collection provides an interesting window into the popular culture of the 1960's and early 1970's. It also reflects the social issues of the time, in particular the anti-war movement, which features in several advertising campaigns (
                <emph render="italic">Some Toys Don't Like War</emph>, for Georg Jensen, and a series of political ads urging a vote on the war).
